hanzi-su-wiki:
貫

Значения

Пронизывать, проходить насквозь; добиваться своего, достигать; мера веса 3,75 кг

Мнемоника

Нанизывать раковины 貝 на нитку в виде связок (сверху).

Варианты

贯
purpleculture_pinyin:
guàn
to pierce through; to pass through; to be stringed together; string of 1000 cash
пробить насквозь; пройти; быть связанными вместе; цепочка из 1000 наличных
rtega_mnemonic:
貫貫RS
贯贯		a string of (1,000) holed copper coins, pierce through, be linked together
  • money 貝 pierced through 毌 hanging on a string
purpleculture_info:
(Simplified: 贯)
Pictophonetic: 毌 indicates the sound; 貝 (money) conveys the meaning.
purpleculture_examples:
貫徹 [ guàn chè ]: to implement; to put into practice; to carry out
貫穿 [ guàn chuān ]: to run through; a connecting thread from beginning to end; to link
貫通 [ guàn tōng ]: to link up; to thread together
purpleculture_tree:
• ⿱ Above to below
    • 毌 [ guàn ] old form of 貫
    • 貝 [ bèi ] sea shell; money, currency
heisig_chinese_memo: Ariel the Little Mermaid's clamshell bra was held to her breasts by piercings (pierce).
heisig_constituent: pierce, mama, mother, breasts, oyster, shellfish, clam, oyster, eye, animal legs, eight
heisig_story: If one is asked to think of associations for the word pierce, among the first to come to mind is that of piercing one's ears to hold earrings, a quite primitive form of self-mutilation that has survived into the 21st century. The kanji here is read, top to bottom: mama . . . oyster. All you need to do is imagine piercing an ear so that it can hold a mother-of-pearl (actually, a mama-of-pearl) you have just wrested from an oyster.
koohiiStory1: Ariel the Little Mermaid´s clamshell bra was held to her breasts by piercings.
koohiiStory2: The sad fate of Mama shellfish was to be captured and pierced to make an earring.
jp_example_words:
貫禄(かんろく): presence, dignity
貫く(つらぬく): to go through
WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic:
Under the window, you place a shellfish, then slam the window shut to pierce its tough shell. This is the best way to pierce a member of the shellfish family, I promise.
This kanji also has a second meaning. That shellfish you pierced with the window is in two halves now. You can use those halves as plates for sushi. If you count the broken shells you'll know how much sushi you have. That makes them sushi counters!
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Imagine the window piercing into the shellfish's shell. Then imagine lining up the pieces, putting sushi on them, and counting them all.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: Now that your shellfish is properly pierced and turned into sushi counters, you can serve them to Genghis Khan (かん) and his men. I really hope you counted them correctly too, because there are a lot of them.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Carefully count out all the sushi on their pierced shell plates and place them in front of Genghis Khan and his army. As you reach Genghis Khan himself, you realize it's just his ghost, but he's still staring at you as you serve his troops. Ghost or not, you don't want him to pierce you if you mess up.
Ru_Radicals: ハ, 毋 (нельзя), 目 (глаз), 母 (мать), 貝 (раковина)
Ru_trainchinese: guàn: (графема/сч.слово) проходить через; соединять; быть сведущим в; заходить/выходить один за другим; родные места; (устар., счетное слово) связка (из 1000 монет)
Kanshudo_mnemonic: the mother (毌) over the shellfish (貝) pierces it
chinese_mnemonics_deck__story: The shellfish pierced through the rice field trying to find its way back to water.
humanum_full_description_en:
Elaboration: The inscription from the second " shell " to "丨" means that the money shell is stringed together with a rope. The original meaning is to wear the money shell rope. Later it means to penetrate, penetrate, connect and connect. By colluding things and connecting things together, it leads to the continuity of time and the meaning of connection (Shirakawa Jing). The word " habit ", which is derived from " guan " as both sound and meaning symbols, is also derived from the meaning of being familiar with all kinds of things.

Inscriptions indicate through, the opening of the earthenware vessel: "Wang Ling first province in the south or (country), and through the line." " Middle " is the name, which means Zhou Wang took the lead patrol southern command, through road (Qiu Xigui).
humanum_short_description_en: Inscriptions from the two " shells " to "丨", like the shape of two shell coins with a rope. The original meaning is the rope that runs through the Qianbei, that is, the string of money, which is extended to penetrate, penetrate, connect, and connect.
humanum_full_description:
金文從二「貝」從「丨」，表示用繩把錢貝串起來，本義是穿錢貝的繩。後來表示貫穿、貫通、串連、連結。由將東西串通連貫起來，引申出時間的連貫連續，及處所的關聯之義（白川靜）。從「貫」為聲符兼意符的「慣」字，也是從心竅貫通，熟習各種事情的意涵引申來的。

　　金文表示貫通、開通，中甗：「王令中先省南或（國），貫行。」「中」是人名，意謂周王命令中率先巡視南國，貫通道路（裘錫圭）。
humanum_short_description: 金文從二「貝」從「丨」，象用繩穿起兩個貝幣之形。本義是貫穿錢貝的繩索，即錢串，引申為貫穿、貫通、串連、連結。

①古代穿錢的繩索(把方孔錢穿在繩子上，每一千個爲一貫)：“貫朽而不可校”。腰纏萬貫。
②穿，通，連：貫穿。貫串。貫通(ａ．連接，溝通；b．對學術等全部透徹地瞭解)。連貫。貫注。貫徹。貫珠(連珠成串，常用來形容聲音的圓潤動聽)。魚貫而入。
③古同“慣”，習慣。
④原籍，出生地：籍貫。
⑤姓氏。

金文從二「 貝 」從「 丨 」，表示用繩把錢貝串起來，本義是穿錢貝的繩。後來表示貫穿、貫通、串連、連結。由將東西串通連貫起來，引申出時間的連貫連續，及處所的關聯之義（白川靜）。從「 貫 」為聲符兼意符的「 慣 」字，也是從心竅貫通，熟習各種事情的意涵引申來的。 金文表示貫通、開通，中甗：「王令中先省南或（國），貫行。」「 中 」是人名，意謂周王命令中率先巡視南國，貫通道路（裘錫圭）。

Later it means to penetrate, penetrate, connect and connect. By colluding things and connecting things together, it leads to the continuity of time and the meaning of connection (Shirakawa Jing). The word " habit", which is derived from " guan" as both sound and meaning symbols, is also derived from the meaning of being familiar with all kinds of things. Inscriptions indicate through, the opening of the earthenware vessel: "Wang Ling first province in the south or (country), and through the line." " Middle" is the name, which means Zhou Wang took the lead patrol southern command, through road (Qiu Xigui).

貫字的基本解释

貫
guàn
见“贯”。

貫字的汉语字典释义

[①]［guàn］
［《廣韻》古玩切，去换，見。］
［《廣韻》古丸切，平桓，見。］
“贯1”的繁体字。
(1)串钱的绳索。
(2)泛指串其他东西的绳索。
(3)古代铜钱用绳穿，千钱为一贯。
(4)串连；连结。
(5)累；连续。参见“貫日”、“貫辰”。
(6)穿戴。
(7)通，贯通。
(8)射中；穿透。
(9)指穿刺。
(10)经历；经过。
(11)侍奉，服事。
(12)引申为仕宦。
(13)事情，事例。
(14)条理；系统。
(15)序次；按顺序排列。
(16)灌注；注入。
(17)满。
(18)罪恶。
(19)祖籍；籍贯。
(20)谓登记入籍。
(21)焙茶用具。
(22)通“丱”。儿童束发成两角的样子。
(23)用同“冠”。
(24)通“摜”。参见“貫跤”。
(25)古国名。
(26)姓。汉有贯高。见《史记·张耳陈馀列传》。
[②]［guàn］
［《集韻》古患切，去諫，見。］
“贯2”的繁体字

貫字的康熙字典解释

【酉集中】【貝字部】　貫； 康熙笔画：11； 页码：页1205第17
【唐韻】【集韻】【韻會】【正韻】?古玩切，音瓘。【說文】貫，錢貝之貫。【前漢·食貨志】京師之錢累百鉅萬，貫朽而不可校。　又【博雅】穿也。【五經文字】旣穿曰貫。【易·剝卦】貫魚。【釋文】貫，穿也。【前漢·董仲舒傳】豈不同條共貫與。【註】貫者，聮絡貫穿。　又中也。【儀禮·鄕射禮】不貫不釋。【註】貫，猶中也。　又【穀梁傳·昭十九年】羈貫成童。【註】羈貫，謂交午剪髮以爲飾。　又【晉書·文苑傳】架彼辭人，共超淸貫。【正字通】侍從之官曰淸貫。　又姓。【姓氏急就篇】趙相貫高。【古音略】貫高之貫，音冠。　又【博雅】累也。　又【韻府】本貫，鄕籍也。　又國名。【括地志】故貫城卽古貫國，在曹州濟隂縣。　又【詩·魏風】三歲貫女。【傳】貫，事也。【釋文】古亂反。○按朱傳：貫，習也。音慣。　又【集韻】【正韻】?古患切，音慣。慣，亦作貫。【爾雅·釋詁】貫，習也。【詩·齊風】射則貫兮。【釋文】毛古亂反，中也。鄭古患反，習也。【前漢·賈誼傳】習慣如自然。【註】師古曰：貫，亦習也

Traditional characters for "贯1".
(1) The rope for stringing money.
(2) Generally refers to the rope that strung other things.
(3) Ancient copper coins were worn with ropes, and thousands of coins were consistent.
(4) Concatenation; link.
(5) Tired; continuous. See "Guanri" and "Guanchen".
(6) Wear.
(7) Through, through.
(8) Hit; penetrate.
(9) Refers to puncture.
(10) Experience; after.
(11) Serve, serve.
(12) By extension, it is official.
(13) Things, examples.
(14) Order; system.
(15) Order; Arrange in order.
(16) Perfusion; injection.
(17) Full.
(18) Sin.
(19) Ancestral home; hometown.
(20) It is called naturalization registration.
(21) Roasted tea utensils.
(22) Through "丱". The child's hair is tied in two horns.
(23) Use the same as "Crown".
(24) Through "掼". See "Guanju".
(25) Ancient country names.
(26) Last name. Han has Guan Gao. See "Historical Biography of Zhang Er and Chen Yu".
[②]［guàn］
["Jiyun" ancient troubles, go to admonish, see. ]

Name meaning

guàn, wān
вм. 贯
Radicals: 毋, 貝  (window, shellfish)
Meaning Mnemonic
Under the window, you place a shellfish, then slam the window shut to pierce its tough shell. This is the best way to pierce a member of the shellfish family, I promise.
This kanji also has a second meaning. That shellfish you pierced with the window is in two halves now. You can use those halves as plates for sushi. If you count the broken shells you'll know how much sushi you have. That makes them sushi counters!
Imagine the window piercing into the shellfish's shell. Then imagine lining up the pieces, putting sushi on them, and counting them all.
Reading Mnemonic
Now that your shellfish is properly pierced and turned into sushi counters, you can serve them to Genghis Khan (かん) and his men. I really hope you counted them correctly too, because there are a lot of them.
Carefully count out all the sushi on their pierced shell plates and place them in front of Genghis Khan and his army. As you reach Genghis Khan himself, you realize it's just his ghost, but he's still staring at you as you serve his troops. Ghost or not, you don't want him to pierce you if you mess up.

Examples: 貫く (つらぬ.く)
ハ, 毋 (нельзя), 目 (глаз), 母 (мать), 貝 (раковина)
